This significantly reduces the chance of an attacker being able to bypass any protection mechanisms that are in the base program but not in the include files. It will also reduce the attack surface.

  8. Understand all the potential areas where untrusted inputs can enter your software: parameters or arguments, cookies, anything read from the network, environment variables, reverse DNS lookups, query results, request headers, URL components, e-mail, files, filenames, databases, and any external systems that provide data to the application. Remember that such inputs may be obtained indirectly through API calls.

Many file inclusion problems occur because the programmer assumed that certain inputs could not be modified, especially for cookies and URL components.

  9. Use an application firewall that can detect attacks against this weakness. It can be beneficial in cases in which the code cannot be fixed (because it is controlled by a third party), as an emergency prevention measure while more comprehensive software assurance measures are applied, or to provide defense in depth.
sast.shortDescription: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

sast.description: Setting the `autoescape` attribute to `false` disables the escaping mechanism of the Swig template engine. This may lead to XSS attack if untrusted data is not properly validated and escaped.

events.description: Setting the `autoescape` attribute to `false` disables the escaping mechanism of the Swig template engine. This may lead to XSS attack if untrusted data is not properly validated and escaped.
Set the `autoescape` attribute to `true`, or omit it as the default value is `true`.

sast.name: sigma.expression_escaping_disabled:swig|javascript
sast.remediation:
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

For example, consider using the ESAPI Encoding control [REF-45] or a similar tool, library, or framework. These will help the programmer encode outputs in a manner less prone to error.

Alternately, use built-in functions, but consider using wrappers in case those functions are discovered to have a vulnerability.

  2. If available, use structured mechanisms that automatically enforce the separation between data and code. These mechanisms may be able to provide the relevant quoting, encoding, and validation automatically, instead of relying on the developer to provide this capability at every point where output is generated.

For example, stored procedures can enforce database query structure and reduce the likelihood of SQL injection.

  3. Understand the context in which your data will be used and the encoding that will be expected. This is especially important when transmitting data between different components, or when generating outputs that can contain multiple encodings at the same time, such as web pages or multi-part mail messages. Study all expected communication protocols and data representations to determine the required encoding strategies.
  4. In some cases, input validation may be an important strategy when output encoding is not a complete solution. For example, you may be providing the same output that will be processed by multiple consumers that use different encodings or representations. In other cases, you may be required to allow user-supplied input to contain control information, such as limited HTML tags that support formatting in a wiki or bulletin board. When this type of requirement must be met, use an extremely strict allowlist to limit which control sequences can be used. Verify that the resulting syntactic structure is what you expect. Use your normal encoding methods for the remainder of the input.
  5. Use input validation as a defense-in-depth measure to reduce the likelihood of output encoding errors (see CWE-20).
  6. Fully specify which encodings are required by components that will be communicating with each other.
  7. When exchanging data between components, ensure that both components are using the same character encoding. Ensure that the proper encoding is applied at each interface. Explicitly set the encoding you are using whenever the protocol allows you to do so.
sast.shortDescription: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output

sast.description: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.

events.description: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.
Explicitly set the `read-only` attribute of the service to `true` to create a service container with a read-only filesystem.

sast.name: sigma.container_filesystem_write:docker_compose|text
sast.remediation: Restrict file-level access to only those actors where it is reasonable and necessary.
sast.shortDescription: Files or Directories Accessible to External Parties

sast.description:
The application uses an anchor tag whose `target` attribute is set to `_blank`, but the `rel` attribute is not set with the `noopener` value. The page opened from that target link may have the access to the `location` object of the original page through `window.opener.location`. A malicious page associated with this link will be able to navigate the original page to an arbitrary site, such as a phishing site, and thus, execute a reverse tabnabbing attack.
Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.

events.description:
The application uses an anchor tag whose `target` attribute is set to `_blank`, but the `rel` attribute is not set with the `noopener` value. The page opened from that target link may have the access to the `location` object of the original page through `window.opener.location`. A malicious page associated with this link will be able to navigate the original page to an arbitrary site, such as a phishing site, and thus, execute a reverse tabnabbing attack.
Note that most contemporary browsers add the `noopener` value to the `rel` automatically by default. Thus, only users with older versions of browsers are targets for this phishing attack.
Set the `rel` attribute to include the `noopener` value, thus disallowing the linked page to access the original page through the `window.opener` object.

sast.name: sigma.reverse_tabnabbing:html|html
sast.remediation:
To prevent untrusted pages linked from the application from being able to manipulate the "window.opener" object, set the attribute rel="noopener noreferrer" for each HTML link to external sites. In addition to preventing reverse tabnabbing attacks, it may also improve browser performance as the new page can be run in a separate process.

When the rel attribute is set to "noopener", the "window.opener" object is "null" on the new page. Therefore, the attacker cannot manipulate the navigation of the original page.  Additionally, the "noreferrer" attribute tells the browser to not include referrer information when the new page is requested.

For links opened with JavaScript, add the values "noopener", "noreferrer" as the "windowFeatures" parameter in the "window.open()" function:
```
var childWindow = window.open(url, name, "noopener,noreferrer");   
```
For legacy browser support, you can also manually set the opener to "null":
```
childWindow.opener = null;  
```

**Note**: The rel="noopener" attribute setting is supported by most modern browsers such as Firefox, Chrome, Edge and Safari but is not supported by legacy browsers such as Internet Explorer. For the latest information on browser support, refer to https://caniuse.com/#search=rel.

sast.description: User-controlled input is used to specify an address that is used as a URL redirect or forward. An attacker can create a link to the trusted site that redirects to a malicious web site. This could enable the attacker to steal user credentials. An attacker can mount a phishing attack by modifying the URL value to point to a malicious Web site.

events.description: req.query is a source of tainted data

User-controlled input is used to specify an address that is used as a URL redirect or forward. An attacker can create a link to the trusted site that redirects to a malicious web site. This could enable the attacker to steal user credentials. An attacker can mount a phishing attack by modifying the URL value to point to a malicious Web site.
Validate whether the url being redirected or forwarded is present in the set of known safe URLs or redirects to a webpage from the same domain.

sast.name: sigma.open_redirect:core_javascript|javascript
sast.remediation:
URLs constructed using untrusted data should be validated against a domain allow-list prior to redirect; when unvalidated redirects are required by the business, the application should request the user's permission prior to issuing the redirect.

When possible, the URL used to issue a redirect should not come from the client. If a redirect can be issued to one of a set of known URLs, a token representing the URL should be passed to the client and then matched against the corresponding URL on the server during the initial redirect request rather than passing the entire URL from the client.

If building a complete list of valid URLs is infeasible, the application should maintain a allow-list of safe domains on the server, and only accept local paths to pages or resources which it then appends to the domain in server-side logic. For example, an application may only want to redirect users within the domain "http://myhost.com". To prevent the redirect URL from exposing users to potentially unsafe sites, the application should only accept local paths (e.g. "/app1/index.jsp") from the user. The application logic should then be responsible for validating the data and constructing the redirect URL by combining the allow-listed domain with the user-provided path.

If the application must provide an open redirect function and cannot make any assumptions about the redirect destination URL, then the application should display an intermediate page that asks the user for confirmation prior to redirect.

sast.description: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.

events.description: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.
Disable container privilege escalation by explicitly setting `no-new-privileges` to `true`.

sast.name: sigma.container_privilege_escalation_allowed:docker_compose|text
sast.remediation:
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Very carefully manage the setting, management, and handling of privileges. Explicitly manage trust zones in the software.
  2. Follow the principle of least privilege when assigning access rights to entities in a software system.
  3. Consider following the principle of separation of privilege. Require multiple conditions to be met before permitting access to a system resource.

sast.description: Code can never be reached because of a logical contradiction

events.description: Condition "cookieEnabled", taking true branch. Now the value of "cookieEnabled" cannot be equal to 0.
Condition "cookieEnabled", taking true branch. The truth value of "cookieEnabled" must be true.
Condition "cookieEnabled", taking true branch. Now the type of "cookieEnabled" cannot be any of undefined, null and NaN.
At condition "cookieEnabled === null", the value of "cookieEnabled" cannot be equal to 0.
At condition "cookieEnabled === null", the truth value of "cookieEnabled" must be true.
At condition "cookieEnabled === null", the type of "cookieEnabled" cannot be any of undefined, null and NaN.
The condition "cookieEnabled === null" cannot be true.
Execution cannot reach this statement: "document.cookie = "testcook...".

sast.localEffect: The indicated dead code may have performed some action; that action will never occur.
sast.name: deadcode:logical_contradiction|javascript
sast.remediation: Unreachable and dead code should be analyzed and either removed or corrected depending on whether it is needed. If the code should execute but doesn't, any bugs preventing the code from executing must be fixed. If the code is not needed, and its removal will not have a negative impact on the application, it should be removed.

sast.description: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

events.description: The `sandbox` attribute of an `iframe` is not set in HTML. This iframe loads content from a third-party site. If the JavaScript in that iframe is malicious or was compromised, an attacker can break out of the iframe, access the DOM of the main page, and mount a clickjacking or a phishing attack.

Enable all restrictions by setting the `sandbox` attribute of the `iframe` to an empty value, or just allow necessary capabilities by setting the `sandbox` attribute with specific value(`allow-forms`, `allow-modals`, `allow-scripts`, etc.). Avoid setting both `allow-scripts` and `allow-same-origin` at the same time as they are a vulnerable attributes combination.

sast.name: sigma.missing_iframe_sandbox:html|html
sast.remediation:
Potential mitigations include the following:
  1. Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.
  2. When the set of acceptable objects, such as filenames or URLs, is limited or known, create a mapping from a set of fixed input values (such as numeric IDs) to the actual filenames or URLs, and reject all other inputs.

For example, ID 1 could map to "inbox.txt" and ID 2 could map to "profile.txt". Features such as the ESAPI AccessReferenceMap [REF-45] provide this capability.

  3. For any security checks that are performed on the client side, ensure that these checks are duplicated on the server side, in order to avoid CWE-602. Attackers can bypass the client-side checks by modifying values after the checks have been performed, or by changing the client to remove the client-side checks entirely. Then, these modified values would be submitted to the server.
  4. Run the code in a "jail" or similar sandbox environment that enforces strict boundaries between the process and the operating system. This may effectively restrict which files can be accessed in a particular directory or which commands can be executed by the software.

OS-level examples include the Unix chroot jail, AppArmor, and SELinux. In general, managed code may provide some protection. For example, java.io.FilePermission in the Java SecurityManager allows the software to specify restrictions on file operations.

This may not be a feasible solution, and it only limits the impact to the operating system; the rest of the application may still be subject to compromise.

Be careful to avoid CWE-243 and other weaknesses related to jails.

  5. Run your code using the lowest privileges that are required to accomplish the necessary tasks [REF-76]. If possible, create isolated accounts with limited privileges that are only used for a single task. That way, a successful attack will not immediately give the attacker access to the rest of the software or its environment. For example, database applications rarely need to run as the database administrator, especially in day-to-day operations.
  6. Assume all input is malicious. Use an "accept known good" input validation strategy, i.e., use a list of acceptable inputs that strictly conform to specifications. Reject any input that does not strictly conform to specifications, or transform it into something that does.

When performing input validation, consider all potentially relevant properties, including length, type of input, the full range of acceptable values, missing or extra inputs, syntax, consistency across related fields, and conformance to business rules. As an example of business rule logic, "boat" may be syntactically valid because it only contains alphanumeric characters, but it is not valid if the input is only expected to contain colors such as "red" or "blue."

Do not rely exclusively on looking for malicious or malformed inputs. This is likely to miss at least one undesirable input, especially if the code's environment changes. This can give attackers enough room to bypass the intended validation. However, denylists can be useful for detecting potential attacks or determining which inputs are so malformed that they should be rejected outright.

When validating filenames, use stringent allowlists that limit the character set to be used. If feasible, only allow a single "." character in the filename to avoid weaknesses such as CWE-23, and exclude directory separators such as "/" to avoid CWE-36. Use a list of allowable file extensions, which will help to avoid CWE-434.

Do not rely exclusively on a filtering mechanism that removes potentially dangerous characters. This is equivalent to a denylist, which may be incomplete (CWE-184). For example, filtering "/" is insufficient protection if the filesystem also supports the use of "\" as a directory separator. Another possible error could occur when the filtering is applied in a way that still produces dangerous data (CWE-182). For example, if "../" sequences are removed from the ".../...//" string in a sequential fashion, two instances of "../" would be removed from the original string, but the remaining characters would still form the "../" string.

  7. Store library, include, and utility files outside of the web document root, if possible. Otherwise, store them in a separate directory and use the web server's access control capabilities to prevent attackers from directly requesting them. One common practice is to define a fixed constant in each calling program, then check for the existence of the constant in the library/include file; if the constant does not exist, then the file was directly requested, and it can exit immediately.

This significantly reduces the chance of an attacker being able to bypass any protection mechanisms that are in the base program but not in the include files. It will also reduce the attack surface.

  8. Understand all the potential areas where untrusted inputs can enter your software: parameters or arguments, cookies, anything read from the network, environment variables, reverse DNS lookups, query results, request headers, URL components, e-mail, files, filenames, databases, and any external systems that provide data to the application. Remember that such inputs may be obtained indirectly through API calls.

Many file inclusion problems occur because the programmer assumed that certain inputs could not be modified, especially for cookies and URL components.

  9. Use an application firewall that can detect attacks against this weakness. It can be beneficial in cases in which the code cannot be fixed (because it is controlled by a third party), as an emergency prevention measure while more comprehensive software assurance measures are applied, or to provide defense in depth.
sast.shortDescription: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere

sca.name: fstream

vulnerabilities.description: fstream is vulnerable to an arbitrary file overwrite issue. Attackers could exploit this via hardlink within the `fstream.DirWriter` function, allowing for the overwriting of files on the system enabling the attacker to launch other attacks by editing, or replacing files.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2019-13173
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**1.0.12**](https://github.com/npm/fstream/releases/tag/v1.0.12) by [this](https://github.com/npm/fstream/commit/6a77d2fa6e1462693cf8e46f930da96ec1b0bb22) commit.

The latest stable releases are also available [here](https://github.com/npm/fstream/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Link Resolution Before File Access ('Link Following')

sca.name: node-semver

vulnerabilities.description: Node Semver is vulnerable due to improper handling of whitespaces. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by providing a crafted input in order to cause a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-25883
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:
* [**7.5.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases/tag/v7.5.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/commit/717534ee353682f3bcf33e60a8af4292626d4441) commit,
* [**6.3.1**](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases/tag/v6.3.1) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/commit/928e56d21150da0413a3333a3148b20e741a920c) commit,
* [**5.7.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases/tag/v5.7.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/commit/2f8fd41487acf380194579ecb6f8b1bbfe116be0) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/npm/node-semver/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Regular Expression

sca.name: gruntjs

vulnerabilities.description:
Grunt is vulnerable to an remote code execution (RCE) issue due to how the `load()` function is used by default to load YAML files.

An attacker could provide a crafted YAML file that, when loaded, could generate executable code and allow the attacker to run arbitrary code on the system.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-7729
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**1.3.0**](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases/tag/v1.3.0) by [this](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/commit/e350cea1724eb3476464561a380fb6a64e61e4e7) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

vulnerabilities.description: GruntJS contains a TOCTOU (Time of Check to Time of Use) race condition. An attacker with low-level privileges could exploit this issue by creating a symlink at a specific time. This may lead to the ability for an attacker to arbitrarily write files and potentially allow for local privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-1537
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.5.3**](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases/tag/v1.5.3) by [this](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/commit/58016ffac5ed9338b63ecc2a63710f5027362bae) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition

vulnerabilities.description: grunt is vulnerable to a symlink following flaw that allows path traversal. If the application is run with high privileges this could allow a local attacker to read and write protected system files.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-0436
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.5.0**](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases/tag/v1.5.0) by [this](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/commit/aad3d4521c3098fb255fb2db8f2e1d691a033665) commit.

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

sca.name: minimist

vulnerabilities.description:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-7598
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.2.6**](https://github.com/substack/minimist/releases/tag/1.2.6) by [this](https://github.com/substack/minimist/commit/c2b981977fa834b223b408cfb860f933c9811e4d) commit. 

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/substack/minimist/tags)
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-44906
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.2.6**](https://github.com/substack/minimist/releases/tag/1.2.6) by [this](https://github.com/substack/minimist/commit/c2b981977fa834b223b408cfb860f933c9811e4d) commit. 

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/substack/minimist/tags)
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: Request package contains a vulnerability that can allow server side request forgery (SSRF) attacks using cross-protocol redirects. This vulnerability can be exploited even if there are anti-SSRF filtering measures in place.

sca.name: moment/moment

vulnerabilities.description: moment is vulnerable to path traversal which may lead to the modification of sensitive information within a file directory on the file system. An attacker can exploit this flaw by manipulating directory pathways using unwanted characters to access and modify a resource that is outside the intended directory.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-24785
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**2.29.2**](https://github.com/moment/moment/releases/tag/2.29.2) by [this](https://github.com/moment/moment/commit/4211bfc8f15746be4019bba557e29a7ba83d54c5) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Directory Traversal
vulnerabilities.workaround:
The vendor has stated [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-8hfj-j24r-96c4) the following workaround:

"Sanitize user-provided locale name before passing it to moment.js".

vulnerabilities.description:
Moment.js is vulnerable to a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issue due to an inefficient regular expression in use within the `rfc2822` parsing code.

An attacker could submit a crafted input containing more that 10,000 characters in order to trigger an excessive consumption of resources that result in a slowdown of processing.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-31129
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**2.29.4**](https://github.com/moment/moment/releases/tag/2.29.4) by [this](https://github.com/moment/moment/commit/9a3b5894f3d5d602948ac8a02e4ee528a49ca3a3) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/moment).

**Note**: The vendor has stated in their [advisory](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-wc69-rhjr-hc9g) that the patch for **2.29.4** can be applied to all affected versions with minimal tweaking.
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Regular Expression
vulnerabilities.workaround: The vendor has suggested [here](https://github.com/moment/moment/security/advisories/GHSA-wc69-rhjr-hc9g) that users of Moment.js who pass a user-supplied string to a constructor should apply input length filters to help with this issue, and other potential future regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) issues.

sca.name: Lodash

vulnerabilities.description: lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker may be able to supply specially crafted input to cause serious confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts to the application. In the past, such vulnerabilities have lead to remote code execution (RCE) in the end application.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-3839
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2018-16487
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**4.17.11**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.11) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/90e6199a161b6445b01454517b40ef65ebecd2ad) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-23337
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**4.17.21**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.21) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/3469357cff396a26c363f8c1b5a91dde28ba4b1c) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2019-10744
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version **[4.17.12](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.12-npm)** with [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/793f983629f5ccef831360f4d31881bbf6264f8b) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://lodash.com/).
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2019-3842
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-8203
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

vulnerabilities.description: lodash.set is vulnerable to prototype pollution. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-4901
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in lodash version [**4.17.16**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.16) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/c84fe82760fb2d3e03a63379b297a1cc1a2fce12) commit.

**Note**: lodash.set is no longer maintained as its own exported Node.js module.
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-2147
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in [**4.17.19**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.19).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or create a denial-of-service (DoS).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2018-3721
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**4.17.5**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.5) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/d8e069cc3410082e44eb18fcf8e7f3d08ebe1d4a) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://lodash.com/).
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-28500
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in [**4.17.21**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.21) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/c4847ebe7d14540bb28a8b932a9ce1b9ecbfee1a) commit.
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient validation of user provided paths in the `_.unset` and `_.omit` functions. This could allow a remote attacker to delete methods from global prototypes by using a maliciously crafted path.

**Note:** The vendor has stated that this issue does not allow for the behavior of properties to be overwritten, only deleted.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2025-13465
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:
* [**4.17.23**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23)
* [**4.17.23-amd**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23-amd)
* [**4.17.23-es**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23-es)
* [**4.17.23-npm**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23-npm)

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Mass Assignment

vulnerabilities.description: lodash prior to 4.17.11 is affected by: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption. The impact is: Denial of service. The component is: Date handler. The attack vector is: Attacker provides very long strings, which the library attempts to match using a regular expression. The fixed version is: 4.17.11.

sca.name: send

vulnerabilities.description: send is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) via template injection. Developers can unknowingly expose themselves to increased risk of XSS because passing untrusted user input to the steam redirect function may execute the untrusted code, even if it has supposedly been sanitized. A remote attacker could insert JavaScript code in order to steal a victim's session tokens, cookies, or other sensitive information.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2024-43799
vulnerabilities.solution:

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/pillarjs/send/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Cross-site Scripting
vulnerabilities.workaround:
As per the [Advisory](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-m6fv-jmcg-4jfg).

> "users are encouraged to upgrade to the patched version of express, but otherwise can workaround this issue by making sure any untrusted inputs are safe, ideally by validating them against an explicit allowlist"

sca.name: npm-cli

vulnerabilities.description: An issue was discovered in an npm 5.7.0 2018-02-21 pre-release (marked as "next: 5.7.0" and therefore automatically installed by an "npm upgrade -g npm" command, and also announced in the vendor's blog without mention of pre-release status). It might allow local users to bypass intended filesystem access restrictions because ownerships of /etc and /usr directories are being changed unexpectedly, related to a "correctMkdir" issue.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2018-7408
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

vulnerabilities.description:
npm cli Incorrect Permission Assignment Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability. This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected installations of npm cli. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute low-privileged code on the target system in order to exploit this vulnerability.

The specific flaw exists within the handling of modules. The application loads modules from an unsecured location. An attacker can leverage this vulnerability to escalate privileges and execute arbitrary code in the context of a target user. Was ZDI-CAN-25430.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2026-0775
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

sca.name: decode-uri-component

A remote attacker may be able to abuse this issue in order to execute arbitrary code, obtain privileges, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

sca.name: Node Cookie Parser

vulnerabilities.description: cookie contains an input validation vulnerability. This could allow an attacker to inject values into the cookie `name` field which should not be allowed and may result in other fields of the cookie being escaped or containing unexpected values. This vulnerability also exists in the `path` and the `domain` field, allowing their values to alter the values of other cookie fields.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2024-47764
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**0.7.0**](https://github.com/jshttp/cookie/releases/tag/v0.7.0) by [this](https://github.com/jshttp/cookie/commit/e10042845354fea83bd8f34af72475eed1dadf5c) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/jshttp/cookie/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Injection in Downstream Component
vulnerabilities.workaround:
The vendor has suggested the following workaround:
> Avoid passing untrusted or arbitrary values for these fields, ensure they are set by the application instead of user input.

sca.name: Lodash

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2019-10744
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version **[4.17.12](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.12-npm)** with [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/793f983629f5ccef831360f4d31881bbf6264f8b) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://lodash.com/).
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2019-3842
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-8203
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

vulnerabilities.description: lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker may be able to supply specially crafted input to cause serious confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts to the application. In the past, such vulnerabilities have lead to remote code execution (RCE) in the end application.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-3839
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: lodash.set is vulnerable to prototype pollution. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-4901
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in lodash version [**4.17.16**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.16) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/c84fe82760fb2d3e03a63379b297a1cc1a2fce12) commit.

**Note**: lodash.set is no longer maintained as its own exported Node.js module.
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash is vulnerable to command injection via the `template` function. An attacker can take advantage of this vulnerability in order to run arbitrary commands.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-23337
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**4.17.21**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.21) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/3469357cff396a26c363f8c1b5a91dde28ba4b1c) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-2147
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in [**4.17.19**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.19).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-28500
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in [**4.17.21**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.21) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/c4847ebe7d14540bb28a8b932a9ce1b9ecbfee1a) commit.
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient validation of user provided paths in the `_.unset` and `_.omit` functions. This could allow a remote attacker to delete methods from global prototypes by using a maliciously crafted path.

**Note:** The vendor has stated that this issue does not allow for the behavior of properties to be overwritten, only deleted.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2025-13465
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:
* [**4.17.23**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23)
* [**4.17.23-amd**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23-amd)
* [**4.17.23-es**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23-es)
* [**4.17.23-npm**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.23-npm)

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Mass Assignment

vulnerabilities.description: The `package.json` file generated by node package manager for the lodash library contains out-dated information. The `contributors` section of the package.json file contains an URL that has been flagged for serving malware.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2019-0330
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/9ac205216ec7e097095856b971dea625f4da2fe6) commit in the npm branch. It is not yet part of any stable release.

sca.name: inflight

vulnerabilities.description:
A memory leak issue has been detected in Inflight. A local attacker could exploit this in order to cause a denial-of-service (DoS) condition via a crash of the node process or an application crash. 

**Note:** The Inflight project has not been updated for some time and may no longer be maintained.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2017-4131
vulnerabilities.title: Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime
vulnerabilities.workaround:
Currently there is no official fix for this issue, however, some users have discussed potential workarounds in the [vulnerability thread](https://github.com/isaacs/inflight/issues/5):

It may be possible to define specific package overrides to force the use of packages that do not depend on Inflight. Such an approach depends on the availability of packages that have removed the Inflight dependency.

sca.name: mixin-deep

vulnerabilities.description: Mixin-deep is vulnerable to prototype pollution attack. This could allow an attacker to manipulate a function to add or modify properties of `Object.prototype` via a constructor payload. Successfully exploiting results in a denial-of-service (DoS) and code execution may be possible.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2019-10746
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:

* **[1.3.2](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/1.3.2)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/90ee1fab375fccfd9b926df718243339b4976d50) commit.
* **[2.0.1](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/releases/tag/2.0.1)** by [this](https://github.com/jonschlinkert/mixin-deep/commit/8f464c8ce9761a8c9c2b3457eaeee9d404fa7af9) commit.
vulnerabilities.title: Sensitive Data Exposure
vulnerabilities.workaround:
1. Freeze the prototype use Object.freeze (Object.prototype).
2. Require schema validation of JSON input.
3. Avoid using unsafe recursive merge functions.
4. Consider using objects without prototypes (for example, Object.create(null)), breaking the prototype chain and preventing pollution.
5. As a best practice use Map instead of Object.

sca.name: minimist

vulnerabilities.description:
minimist is vulnerable to a prototype pollution attack. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype` via a `constructor` or `__proto__` payload.

**Note**: This issue was not properly fixed and required an additional disclosure as **CVE-2021-44906** (BDSA-2022-0771).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-7598
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.2.6**](https://github.com/substack/minimist/releases/tag/1.2.6) by [this](https://github.com/substack/minimist/commit/c2b981977fa834b223b408cfb860f933c9811e4d) commit. 

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/substack/minimist/tags)
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
Minimist contains a prototype pollution vulnerability. A remote attacker could exploit this issue by adding or modifying properties of `Function.prototype`, which may lead to execution of arbitrary code.

**Note:** This vulnerability occurs from an incomplete fix of **CVE-2020-7598**, where the `Object`, `String` and `Number` prototypes are fixed, but not `Function`.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-44906
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.2.6**](https://github.com/substack/minimist/releases/tag/1.2.6) by [this](https://github.com/substack/minimist/commit/c2b981977fa834b223b408cfb860f933c9811e4d) commit. 

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/substack/minimist/tags)
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

sca.name: babel-traverse

vulnerabilities.description:
Babel Traverse is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution issue due to how the `_evaluate()` function allows for the evaluation of inherited methods. This affects plugins that rely on the `path.evaluate()` or `path.evaluateTruthy()` internal Babel methods.

In cases where Babel is used to compile untrusted code, an attacker could potentially submit specially crafted code that, during compilation, could be evaluated and executed during the compilation process.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2023-45133
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**8.0.0-alpha4**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse/v/8.0.0-alpha.4) and [**7.23.2**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse/v/7.23.2) by [this](https://github.com/babel/babel/commit/b13376b346946e3f62fc0848c1d2a23223314c82) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@babel/traverse).
vulnerabilities.title: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs
vulnerabilities.workaround:
The vendor has provided the following workaround suggestion in their [advisory](https://github.com/babel/babel/security/advisories/GHSA-67hx-6x53-jw92):
> If you cannot upgrade `@babel/traverse` and are using one of the affected packages, upgrade them to their latest version to avoid triggering the vulnerable code path in affected `@babel/traverse` versions:
> 
>     @babel/plugin-transform-runtime v7.23.2
>     @babel/preset-env v7.23.2
>     @babel/helper-define-polyfill-provider v0.4.3
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-corejs2 v0.4.6
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-corejs3 v0.8.5
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-es-shims v0.10.0
>     babel-plugin-polyfill-regenerator v0.5.3

sca.componentURL: [Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://stg.dev.polaris.blackduck.com/portfolio/portfolios/5d4d6184-07f5-4fd1-a024-4345aace406c/portfolio-items/c44a936d-28dd-4bf6-9c10-9e6e51a86928/projects/6feceb14-1105-4721-93f7-9527ef56f17f/components/df39015a-d174-4a81-ba57-2b754a66f429?branchId=a746cffc-6c3b-48ff-b4c4-361525903fac&component=76fdd28b-3699-4874-8487-07334d337826)
sca.name: tar

vulnerabilities.description: The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via insufficient absolute path sanitization.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-32804
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/147e078e5944bfd8d381bf19737e769e41705e4d) commit. 
* [**4.4.14**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.14) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/efc6bb0dbd54df8c7285d7aac12bba959b8387a6)commit.

* [**6.1.1**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.1) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/1f036ca23f64a547bdd6c79c1a44bc62e8115da4) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation
vulnerabilities.workaround: Create a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the entry.path or a filter method which removes entries with absolute paths.

vulnerabilities.description:
The node-tar package is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite issues due to a flaw in the symlink protection measures that allows for an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location.

An attacker could poison the directory cache by first creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink with the same name. This allows the attacker to bypass symlink checks on directories and enable them to extract arbitrary files into potentially sensitive locations. The attacker could use this flaw to overwrite files to enable arbitrary code execution attacks.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-32803
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:
* [**3.2.3**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v3.2.3) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/85d3a942b4064e4ff171f91696fced7975167349) commit,
* [**4.4.15**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.15) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/46fe35083e2676e31c4e0a81639dce6da7aaa356) commit, 
* [**5.0.7**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v5.0.7) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/5987d9a41f6bfbf1ddab1098e1fdcf1a5618f571) commit, 
* [**6.1.2**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.2) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/9dbdeb6df8e9dbd96fa9e84341b9d74734be6c20) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation
vulnerabilities.workaround: It is suggested on [npmjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1771#workarounds) that it is possible to mitigate the vulnerability by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths.

vulnerabilities.description: The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-37701
vulnerabilities.solution:

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Directory Traversal

vulnerabilities.description: The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution via directory cache poisoning.

vulnerabilities.title: Directory Traversal

vulnerabilities.description:
The tar package for Node.js is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite via insufficient relative path sanitization. 

**Note:** This only affects users on Windows systems.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2021-37713
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in:
* [**4.4.18**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v4.4.18) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/52b09e309bcae0c741a7eb79a17ef36e7828b946) commit.

* [**6.1.9**](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.1.9) by [this](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/875a37e3ec031186fc6599f6807341f56c584598) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Directory Traversal

vulnerabilities.description: Node-Tar is vulnerable to path traversal due to insufficient link path sanitization in the 'unpack.ts' file when the `preservePaths` setting is set to false. A local attacker could exploit this issue by using a malicious TAR archive in order to overwrite the content of arbitrary files or achieve remote code execution (RCE) in CI/CD environments or automated pipelines, with the exception of NPM.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2026-23745
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**7.5.3**](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/releases/tag/v7.5.3) by [this](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/commit/340eb285b6d986e91969a1170d7fe9b0face405e) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Directory Traversal

vulnerabilities.description:
Node-Tar is vulnerable to a race condition due to improper handling of unicode path collisions in the `path-reservations.ts` file. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this issue by executing a symbolic link poisoning attack in order to overwrite the content of arbitrary files.

**Note:** This vulnerability only effects platforms which contain case-insensitive or normalization-insensitive filesystems such as macOS APFS.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2026-23950
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**7.5.4**](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/releases/tag/v7.5.4) by [this](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/commit/3b1abfae650056edfabcbe0a0df5954d390521e6) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Handling of Alternate Encoding
vulnerabilities.workaround:
The vendor has provided the following workaround [here](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/security/advisories/GHSA-r6q2-hw4h-h46w):
Users who cannot upgrade promptly, and who are programmatically using node-tar to extract arbitrary tarball data should filter out all `SymbolicLink` entries (as npm does) to defend against arbitrary file writes via this file system entry name collision issue.

vulnerabilities.description: node-tar is vulnerable to arbitrary file creation/overwrite due to path traversal from the improper sanitization of hardlink paths during extraction. An unauthenticated remote attacker could exploit this by supplying a crafted TAR archive, which could potentially bypass path traversal protections and create hardlinks to arbitrary files outside the extraction directory. Successful exploitation could allow for the overwriting of arbitrary files, unauthorized reading of sensitive files and credential stealing.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2026-24842
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**7.5.7**](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/releases/tag/v7.5.7) by [this](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/commit/f4a7aa9bc3d717c987fdf1480ff7a64e87ffdb46) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Directory Traversal

vulnerabilities.description: node-tar is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) condition due to missing limits on sub-folder creation during the folder creation process. An attacker could exploit this by generating a large number of sub-folder in order to consume memory on the system running node-tar and or to crash the Node.js client.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2024-28863
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**6.2.1**](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/releases/tag/v6.2.1) by [this](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/commit/fe8cd57da5686f8695415414bda49206a545f7f7) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

sca.name: Lodash

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) as the user-controllable input to certain functions is not sufficiently checked, allowing an attacker to add or modify existing properties of presumably immutable `Object` data structure. An unauthenticated attacker can leverage this flaw to add arbitrary properties to objects used by the web application which can be leveraged to cause a crash or to prevent the server from responding to all requests.

This vulnerability may also lead to remote code execution (RCE) in some applications, depending on the implementation.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2018-16487
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**4.17.11**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.11) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/90e6199a161b6445b01454517b40ef65ebecd2ad) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or cause remote code execution or a denial-of-service (*DoS*).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2019-10744
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version **[4.17.12](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.12-npm)** with [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/793f983629f5ccef831360f4d31881bbf6264f8b) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://lodash.com/).
vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability.  This is due to multiple methods not validating the length of content supplied to it.  If an application is passing untrusted-input to the Lodash library, it may be possible for an attacker to cause the process to crash, resulting in a DoS condition.

Please note that this issue is not considered by the vendor to be a vulnerability in Lodash, however it could be exploited if an application using Lodash accepts user input without validation and passes it to the affected functions. A pull request was opened to update the Lodash documentation regarding this issue but it was closed and not merged.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2019-3842
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description:
Lodash is vulnerable to remote code execution (RCE) due to the potential to modify the properties of objects in memory. A remote attacker could run arbitrary commands on a vulnerable server, or cause the server to crash, by maliciously crafting an object via the zip functionality of Lodash.

Note: this issue was not properly addressed and required an additional fix and disclosure (**BDSA-2020-3839**).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-8203
vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

vulnerabilities.description: lodash is vulnerable to a prototype pollution flaw. A remote attacker may be able to supply specially crafted input to cause serious confidentiality, integrity and availability impacts to the application. In the past, such vulnerabilities have lead to remote code execution (RCE) in the end application.
vulnerabilities.name: BDSA-2020-3839
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in **[4.17.20](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.20)**.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data

vulnerabilities.description: lodash.set is vulnerable to prototype pollution. A remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary code, or cause a denial-of-service (DoS) by tricking the library into modifying or adding properties of `Object.prototype`.

vulnerabilities.solution:

**Note**: lodash.set is no longer maintained as its own exported Node.js module.

vulnerabilities.title: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a prototype pollution flaw. An attacker could exploit this to modify the component or create a denial-of-service (DoS).

vulnerabilities.title: Weak Input Validation

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to functionality that allows users to influence protoypes. An attacker could cause a vulnerable application to crash by providing malicious input that modifies JavaScript prototypes within the application. It may also be possible for an attacker to modify data that exists within the application.

vulnerabilities.description: Lodash contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources.

vulnerabilities.solution: Fixed in [**4.17.21**](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/releases/tag/4.17.21) by [this](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/c4847ebe7d14540bb28a8b932a9ce1b9ecbfee1a) commit.
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description: lodash prior to 4.17.11 is affected by: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption. The impact is: Denial of service. The component is: Date handler. The attack vector is: Attacker provides very long strings, which the library attempts to match using a regular expression. The fixed version is: 4.17.11.

vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description: The `package.json` file generated by node package manager for the lodash library contains out-dated information. The `contributors` section of the package.json file contains an URL that has been flagged for serving malware.

sca.name: expressjs/express

vulnerabilities.description:
Express.js web framework is vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) due to the improper handling of user input in the `response.redirect()` function. This could allow an attacker to execute JavaScript code on the users browser.

**Note** The attacker must be in control of the input to `response.redirect()` and the user must click before the redirect occurs.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2024-43796
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**4.20.0**](https://github.com/expressjs/express/releases/tag/4.20.0) and [**5.0.0**](https://github.com/expressjs/express/releases/tag/5.0.0) by [this](https://github.com/expressjs/express/commit/54271f69b511fea198471e6ff3400ab805d6b553) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/expressjs/express/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Cross-site Scripting

vulnerabilities.description: qs before 6.10.3, as used in Express before 4.17.3 and other products, allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application because an __ proto__ key can be used. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL that is used to visit the application, such as a[__proto__]=b&a[__proto__]&a[length]=100000000. The fix was backported to qs 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4 (and therefore Express 4.17.3, which has "deps: qs@6.9.7" in its release description, is not vulnerable).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-24999
vulnerabilities.title: Prototype Pollution

vulnerabilities.description: Express.js contains an open redirect vulnerability due to insufficient validation of user supplied URLs. An attacker could exploit this by providing a crafted URL when performing a redirect bypassing the redirect allow list leading to an open redirect.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2024-29041
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**4.19.0**](https://github.com/expressjs/express/releases/tag/4.19.0) and [**5.0.0-beta2**](https://github.com/expressjs/express/releases/tag/5.0.0-beta.2) by [this](https://github.com/expressjs/express/commit/0867302ddbde0e9463d0564fea5861feb708c2dd) commit.

Improved handling for the bypass was added in [**4.19.2**](https://github.com/expressjs/express/releases/tag/4.19.2) and [**5.0.0-beta.3**](https://github.com/expressjs/express/releases/tag/v5.0.0-beta.3) and  by [this](https://github.com/expressjs/express/commit/0b746953c4bd8e377123527db11f9cd866e39f94) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/expressjs/express/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Open URL Redirect
vulnerabilities.workaround: The vendor has stated [here](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rv95-896h-c2vc) the following as a workaround  "The fix for this involves pre-parsing the url string with either `require('node:url').parse` or `new URL`. These are steps you can take on your own before passing the user input string to `res.location` or `res.redirect`."

sca.componentURL: [Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://stg.dev.polaris.blackduck.com/portfolio/portfolios/5d4d6184-07f5-4fd1-a024-4345aace406c/portfolio-items/c44a936d-28dd-4bf6-9c10-9e6e51a86928/projects/6feceb14-1105-4721-93f7-9527ef56f17f/components/1cd0925e-fc8b-4399-b985-eade896509f4?branchId=a746cffc-6c3b-48ff-b4c4-361525903fac&component=34b0d62d-0d29-4007-8673-b94e1d8ee5d9)
sca.name: micromatch/braces

vulnerabilities.description: The braces NPM package is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) via memory exhaustion due to lack of any restriction on the number of input characters it processes. An application that uses the library and accepts remote user input may be susceptible to the attack via a payload containing a large number of "imbalanced braces", `{` characters.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2024-4068
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**3.0.3**](https://github.com/micromatch/braces/releases/tag/3.0.3) by [this](https://github.com/micromatch/braces/commit/415d660c3002d1ab7e63dbf490c9851da80596ff) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/braces).
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description: The braces package for Node.js contains a bad regular expression that causes catastrophic back tracking. If an application is supplying untrusted input to this module, it is possible for an attacker to input a string that will cause the application to hang or possibly crash due to resource exhaustion. This is better known as a regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2018-1109
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**2.3.1**](https://github.com/micromatch/braces/releases/tag/2.3.1) by [this](https://github.com/micromatch/braces/commit/abdafb0cae1e0c00f184abbadc692f4eaa98f451) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/micromatch/braces/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Incorrect Regular Expression

sca.componentURL: [Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://stg.dev.polaris.blackduck.com/portfolio/portfolios/5d4d6184-07f5-4fd1-a024-4345aace406c/portfolio-items/c44a936d-28dd-4bf6-9c10-9e6e51a86928/projects/6feceb14-1105-4721-93f7-9527ef56f17f/components/056cb466-bcc8-43de-840d-6ebd0b831454?branchId=a746cffc-6c3b-48ff-b4c4-361525903fac&component=aaafa54d-8cf5-4c74-9554-20756773f149)
sca.name: tough-cookie

vulnerabilities.description: tough-cookie is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to improper handling of cookies when using `CookieJar` in `rejectPublicSuffixes=false` mode.  An attacker can use this vulnerability to override the global object prototype in order to cause unspecified impacts.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2023-26136
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**4.1.3**](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/releases/tag/v4.1.3) by [this](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/commit/12d474791bb856004e858fdb1c47b7608d09cf6e) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Mass Assignment

vulnerabilities.description: tough-cookie is vulnerable to regular expression denial-of-service (ReDoS) due to improper validation of cookie headers. This could allow an attacker to potentially render services unavailable.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2016-1000232
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in **[2.3.0](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/releases/tag/v2.3.0)** by [this](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/commit/615627206357d997d5e6ff9da158997de05235ae) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption

vulnerabilities.description: By supplying a large HTTP request cookie header to an application using the Tough-Cookie Node.js an attacker could cause the application to consume an excessive amount of CPU.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2017-15010
vulnerabilities.solution:
A [patch](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/pull/97/commits/f1ed420a6a92ea7a5418df6e39e676556bc0c71d) for this issue is available. 

Fixed in [**2.3.3**](https://github.com/salesforce/tough-cookie/releases/tag/v2.3.3)
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

sca.componentURL: [Click Here To See More Details in Polaris](https://stg.dev.polaris.blackduck.com/portfolio/portfolios/5d4d6184-07f5-4fd1-a024-4345aace406c/portfolio-items/c44a936d-28dd-4bf6-9c10-9e6e51a86928/projects/6feceb14-1105-4721-93f7-9527ef56f17f/components/6537c611-bd2e-4ff1-a0c6-682dc657ed61?branchId=a746cffc-6c3b-48ff-b4c4-361525903fac&component=a0f3241f-312d-4407-86a1-3b249b75aee3)
sca.name: gruntjs

vulnerabilities.description:
Grunt is vulnerable to an remote code execution (RCE) issue due to how the `load()` function is used by default to load YAML files.

An attacker could provide a crafted YAML file that, when loaded, could generate executable code and allow the attacker to run arbitrary code on the system.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2020-7729
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**1.3.0**](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases/tag/v1.3.0) by [this](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/commit/e350cea1724eb3476464561a380fb6a64e61e4e7) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases).
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

vulnerabilities.description: GruntJS contains a TOCTOU (Time of Check to Time of Use) race condition. An attacker with low-level privileges could exploit this issue by creating a symlink at a specific time. This may lead to the ability for an attacker to arbitrarily write files and potentially allow for local privilege escalation.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-1537
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.5.3**](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases/tag/v1.5.3) by [this](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/commit/58016ffac5ed9338b63ecc2a63710f5027362bae) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition

vulnerabilities.description: grunt is vulnerable to a symlink following flaw that allows path traversal. If the application is run with high privileges this could allow a local attacker to read and write protected system files.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-0436
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**1.5.0**](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/releases/tag/v1.5.0) by [this](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/commit/aad3d4521c3098fb255fb2db8f2e1d691a033665) commit.

The latest releases can be found [here](https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Third-party component usage

sca.name: hueniverse/hawk

vulnerabilities.description: Node.js Hawk contains a denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability. An attacker can exploit this using crafted regular expressions to exhaust system resources and cause a crash.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-29167
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**9.0.1**](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk/v/9.0.1) by [this](https://github.com/mozilla/hawk/commit/d10d72ca82db967f6c5fcf866ff78e3ca25ce1ab) commit.

The latest stable releases are available [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hawk).
vulnerabilities.title: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption
vulnerabilities.workaround:
The vendor has issued the following workaround:

"`Hawk.authenticate()` accepts the options argument. If that contains host and port, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`".

sca.name: undefsafe

vulnerabilities.description: undefsafe is vulnerable to prototype pollution due to insufficient restrictions being placed on object modification functionality. An attacker that is able to control the input to the `undefsafe()` function could leverage that function to modify the prototype of an object. The exact impact that the attacker can achieve will depend on how the object is used, but could potentially include cross-site scripting (XSS) and remote code execution (RCE).
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2019-10795
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**2.0.3**](https://github.com/remy/undefsafe/releases/tag/v2.0.3) by [this](https://github.com/remy/undefsafe/commit/f272681b3a50e2c4cbb6a8533795e1453382c822) commit.

The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/undefsafe).
vulnerabilities.title: Mass Assignment

sca.name: qs -  QS Querystring

vulnerabilities.description: qs is vulnerable to denial-of-service (DoS) due to the excessive time required to process `proto` properties of the output JavaScript objects. An unauthenticated attacker could send a request with a manipulated `proto` properties and cause the Node server to freeze as it tries to process the input.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2022-24999
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in [**6.10.3**](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.10.3) by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/8b4cc14cda94a5c89341b77e5fe435ec6c41be2d) commit.

The fix was backported by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/e799ba5) commit in:
* [**6.2.4**](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.2.4)
* [**6.3.3**](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.3.3)

* [**6.9.7**](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.9.7)


The latest stable releases can be found [here](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/tags).
vulnerabilities.title: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type

vulnerabilities.description: QS is vulnerable to resource exhaustion due to improper input validation in the `parse.js` file when the `arrayLimit ` option is used for protection. A remote attacker could exploit this issue in order to bypass array limitations and exhaust system memory, which may impact the performance of the application or create a denial-of-service (DoS) condition.
vulnerabilities.name: CVE-2025-15284
vulnerabilities.solution:
Fixed in version [**6.14.1**](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/releases/tag/v6.14.1) by [this](https://github.com/ljharb/qs/commit/3086902ecf7f088d0d1803887643ac6c03d415b9) commit.
